content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" is a bill that excludes space-related income from gross income according to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Space-related income includes income derived from products or services produced or provided in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes income from services provided in outer space, including telecommunications services, from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The exception for telecommunications services, etc., under the "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes certain services provided in outer space from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes certain services provided in outer space from gross income as defined in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This includes transporting property to or from outer space and proportional allocation of income between space-based and earth-based activities. Wages received by employees are exempt from this provision. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" excludes space-related income from gross income for products produced partly in space. The term "produced" includes various methods like created, fabricated, and manufactured. Additionally, any product is excluded from tariffs if it meets certain criteria. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" defines "produced" broadly and exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs if certain conditions are met. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products manufactured in outer space from federal tariffs if produced at a facility owned by United States persons. Benefits are phased out gradually after 2012. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2003" exempts products made in outer space from federal tariffs if produced at a US-owned facility. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation is exempt from federal tariffs if the corporation is a qualified space company at the time of issuance and the stock is acquired by the taxpayer at its original issue in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided.
